TR 6th grade Agents for Change are contributing to a safer and more equitable world through student advocacy and leadership.

Our 6th grade Agents for Change continue to organize peaceful protests and advocate against guns in schools.

On April 20th, (the 19th anniversary of the Columbine school mass shooting) Two Rivers students held a 19-minute protest. Students wore pins bearing the names of slain students and chanted, "My life matters!" and "Enough is enough!" as they marched. They had cars honking and cheering for them as they chanted and waved their signs. These young visionaries are just one of the extraordinary examples of how our school is making the world better #BetterWorldDay. #wearetheboat ELeducation

The Two Rivers Board of Trustees is looking for energetic and committed individuals to join the Board! The Board is responsible for overseeing Two Rivers' Executive Director and the organization's governance and financial health and ensuring that Two Rivers continues to provide high-quality education to its students in accordance with its mission. Terms are three years long and each member is involved in at least one of four committees: 1) Academic Excellence, 2) Governance, 3) Finance, and 4) Development.

If you're interested, please send your resume, along with a brief statement of why you'd like to join the board, to board@tworiverspcs.org. We're accepting applications through April 20. For more background on the Board, please visit https://www.tworiverspcs.org/community/board.

It’s almost Community Showcase time! Join us December 11-14 for an amazing opportunity! We will come together to watch, listen, learn, and celebrate with students as they share out their learning experience after returning from field studies and completing this year’s fall expeditions.The full Showcase schedule is available in our community calendar http://www.tworiverspcs.org/community/community-calendar?cal_date=2017-12-26

Fourth graders delved into anthropological exploration in Jamestown. Seventh graders tackled using physics to design a safe, realistic, and team-focused ropes course. Third graders traveled all over the city researching WDC history, neighborhood by neighborhood. Sixth graders gathered evidence about the costs and benefits of the local sustainable food chain. Pre-kindergarten students studied the connection between physical movement and learning. Second graders met with DC lawmakers...twice...to discuss how citizen involvement can help strengthen litter laws in DC. Check out these pics of their field studies.

As students dive deep into their fall semester expeditions, we continue to be reminded that the Two Rivers standard of approaching the type of real-world problems they seek to answer is a truly special learning design.

Two Rivers continues to shape the evolving education landscape, with particular praise for problem-based instruction models.

‘ED Week’ featured this blog article written by Two Rivers Director of Curriculum and Instruction Jeff Heyck-Williams, highlighting the outstanding collaborative work in problem design done by science teacher, Steve Karig, English teacher, Mo Thomas, and special educator, Shannon Kelley, during last year’s 8th grade spring expedition on the science and ethics of gene editing. #ELeducation #WeAreCrew #EDweek
